div.p: been done to his wife – or rather by her A–e[.] [H]e gave only 3 Hares[.] I abused him for his laziness he said nothing – but flew upon one of the other Hunters who had R–g–d his wife – I faught a Battle – but the poor Cuckold was vanquished by his enemy while they were fighting[.] [H]er ladys hip was Skivping about the Place inexulting within herself at the great love her Husband was exhibiting to the Company he bore towards her[.] Yet he did not give her one uneven word[.] In the evening two Indians came from Lac du Sol to tell me that all their relations were Sick therefore could not go to the Beaver Country untill they recovered which will not be perhaps untill Spring[.] [G]ave them no Tobo[.] Two others came from old barbeu – brought 250 Hare Snares – the making of which col'd 26 branches of beads[.] [R]eceived from the two former 16 Skins furrs – from the latter 3 Skins furrs & 40 Hares[.] The Shaggling Rascals who came from Lac du Sol are of the montagnes family[.]

Mony 26th[.] Sent off the Indians who arrived – not however without expatiating greatly upon Beaver Killing[.] [M]any promises were made – but I believe few will be performed[.] [N]evertheless I Sent Martin with the two Indians who came from lac Du Sol – to see if he could prevail upon to quit that fishing abode and at the same time gather whatever they had & bring all those who were well to the Fort[.] Cold Weather[.]
Thursy 27th[.] Beaulieu & Sutherd took 9 Hares – Collet 7[.]

Friday 28th[.] Sent Collet for his Snow Shoes which are at old Barbeuxs Lodge – as I intend to Send him & Gibeau with Letters to Mr Keith apprehending that Mr Clarke had forgot in the Fall to let Mr Keith Know the time fixed upon for the departure of the Express[.] Beaulieu & Sutherd took 9 Hares in their Collets besides three which the Crows had eaten[.]
Saturday 29th[.] The Ice took over the Grand River in the morning[.] The Boys took 15 Hares to day[.]

Sunday 30th[.] The Collet returned with his Snow – brought 10 Hares – & 100 Snares which I had recommended to the Old BarBeu[.] Arranged him & Gibeau immidiately that they may be off early tomorrow morning[.] Gave for their voyage 40lb weight of Good Dried Mt 2 Cascameats & 10 Hares – besides 2 Pr Shoes 2 flints 4 meases Amn a Pes Spunk & ten Inches Tobacco to the Indian[.]
